div.p: ¶ A reporte of Maiſter Doctor Redmans anſweres, to queſtions propounded him before his death, concernynge certaine poyntes of religion, now beyng with many in controuerſye. Whervnto diuerſe artycles be added, lately ſubſcribed by Maſter Chedſey.
☞ Trye all thynges, and take that whiche is good.

div.head: ¶ The Printer to the Reader.
div.p:
BEcauſe I had harde ſundrye and dyſagreynge reportes of Mayſter Doctor Redmans iudgemente, in certaine pointes of religion at the tyme of his death, & perceyued one daye in Maſter Secreatary Cecilles Chamber at the Courte, a paper briefly conteynyng the ſayinges of Maſter Redman, with the handes of dyuers learned men, ſubſcribed to teſtifye the truth therof. I beſought him to haue the coppye for the ſatiſfaction of many men, and to ſhewe me the truth of the teſtimony writtē, the paper it ſelfe he lent me wyllyngly, whyche (as he told me) he had in the counſel, of the Duke of Northumberlāde to whō the Kynges Maieſtye delyuered it. And for the profe of the matter written, they whoſe names be ſubſcribed had affirmed the ſame partly to him ſelfe, partly to others beſyde the teſtimony of their own handes, thus hauinge the thynge in my handes & perceyuing dayly talke to encreaſe here vpon, I thought it conueniēt to imprint it for the ſatyſfactyon of the more nomber. And making Maſter Cecil
pryuye of myne intent with the reaſons that moued me, he gaue to me two other wrytinges, the one written by Mayſter Doctor Wilkes & belongyng to Maſter Redmans matter, thother of certaine artycles ſubſcribed by Maſter D. Chedſey of Oxford, a man of moch learning, and as it ſemeth yeldyng his affectiō to learnyng, which thing I thought not amiſſe to knytte togeather in one printe, reſeruyng the iudgement of the whole to bee meaſured by charyte, which as Saynte Paule ſayeth: thynketh not euyll, ioyeth not on wyckedneſſe, but ioyeth on truth and ſuffereth al thyngs. &c. In the ſtock wherof, god graunte al the profeſſors of thy word, to plante, and grifte, the growyng of theyr knowledge, that it maye in the ſpreadyng of the bowes brynge forth good fruyte in, worckes lyke the ſtocke.

closer.dateline: At Londō the .xii. day of December. M.D.L.I.

div.head: ¶ A Communication betwene Doctour Redman, lyinge in hys death bed, and Maiſter Nowell, ſcholemayſter in Weſtminſter, and certayne other, touching certayne poyntes of chriſtes religion.
div.p: IN Primis the ſayd Doctour Redman ſent for M. Nowel of hys owne minde, & ſaid, he was willing to cōmon with hym of ſoche matters as he had moued the ſayd D. Redman of a daye or two before. And he beyng deſyred of ye ſaid M. Nowel to declare his mynde concernyng certaine pointes of oure relygyon, fyrſte ſayde, aſke me what ye wyll, and I wyll anſwere you before god trulye as I thinke without any affection to the world or any worldly perſon.
Wytneſſes, Alex. Nowel, Rych. Burton, Ellis Lomas. Iohn Wryght.
2. Itē the ſayd D. Redman ſaid that the ſea of Rome in theſe latter dayes is ſentina malorum, that is, a ſinke of all euyl.

div.head: ❧ Wytneſſes.
div.p: Iohn yonge. Alexander Nowell: Rychard Burton, Ry. Elithorne, Edward Cratford, Ellis Lomas Iohn Wright.
3. Item that purgatory as the ſchole men caught it & vſed it, was vngodly, & that there was no ſoch kynd of purgatory, as they phantaſyed.

div.head: ❧ Wytneſſes.
div.p: Iohn yong, Rychard Elithorn, Iohn Wryght. Alex. Nowel, Ed. Cratford, Rychard Burton, Ellis Lomas.

4. Item that the offering vp of the Sacramēt in Maſſes & Trentalles
for the ſynnes of the dead is vngodly.

div.head: ☞ Wytneſſes.
div.p: Iohn yong, A. Nowel, E. Cratforde, Rycharde Burton, Ellis Lomas.
5. Item that the wicked ar not partakers of the body of Chriſte, but receaue the vtwarde ſacramēt onely.

div.head: ☞ Wytneſſes.
div.p: Iohn yong. Alexander Nowel Rychard Elithorn, Edward Cratforde, Ellis Lomas, Rycharde, Burton, Iohn Wright.

6. Item that the Sacramente oughte not to be caryed aboute in proceſſion, for it is taught what is the vſe of it in theſe wordes, Accipite manducate & bibite, & hoc facite in mei memoriam. Take, eate, and drincke, and doo this in the remembraunce of me.
Iohn yong, Alex. Nowel, Rych. Burton, Ioh. Wryght. El. Cratforde, Ellis Lomas.
7. Item that nothing whych is ſene in the ſacrament, or perceiued wyth any outwarde ſtuffe is to be worſhypped.
Iohn yong, Alex. Nowel, E. Lomas, Ry. Burton.
8. Itē that we receaue not chriſtes body corporaliter, id eſt craſſe, corporally, that is to ſay groſſely, lyke other meates, and lyke as the Caphernites dyd vnderſtand it.
Iohn yong, A. Nowel, R. Burtō El. Cratford, Ellis Lomas. Iohn Wright.
9. Item that we receaue chriſtes body ſic ſpiritualiter vt tamen vere, ſo ſpirituallye, that neuertheleſſe truely.
Iohn yong, A. Nowel, R. Burtō El. Cratford, Ellis Lomas. Iohn Wright.

10. Item as touching tranſubſtantiacion, that ther is not in any of the olde Doctoures anye good ground or ſure profe thereof, or any mention of it, as far as euer he could perceiue, nether that he ſeith what can be aunſwered to the obiections made agaynſt it.
Iohn yonge. Ry. Burton. Ellis Lomas.
11. Itē beyng aſked of Maſter Wilkes, what that was, that was lyfted vp betwene the prieſtes handes. he anſwered: he thought that Chriſt could nether be lyfte vp nor downe.
Iohn yong, Ry. Burton. E. Lomas.
12. Itē that Prieſtes may by the lawe of God marrie wyuez.
Alexander Nowell. Ellis Lomas.

13. That thys propoſition Sola fides iuſtificat, ſo that fides ſignifye
veram viuā & acquieſcentē in Chriſto fidem id eſt amplexum Chriſti. that is to ſaye: Onely fayth doeth iuſtifye, ſo that fayth do ſignifye a true lyuely, and a fayth reſtinge in chriſte, and embraſing Chriſt, is a true godly ſwete & cōfortable doctryne ſo that it be ſo taughte, that the people take none occaſiō of carnal lybertie thereof.
Iohn yong, A. Nowel, R. Burtō Iohn Wright. Ed. Cratford, Ry. Elithorn, Ellis Lomas.
14. Item that our workes cannot deſerue the kingdom of god and lyf • euerlaſtinge.
Iohn yong, Alexander Nowell, Rychard Burton, Ellis Lomas, Edward Cratford, Rychard Elithorn, Iohn Wright.

Item that the ſaid Doctour Redman at ſoche tymes as we the foreſayde perſonnes whych haue ſubſcrybed
heard his communication, concerning the foreſayd pointes of religion, was of quyet mynde and of perfyte remembraunce, as farre as we were able to iudge.
Iohn yong. Alexander Nowel. Rychard Burton. Ellis Lomas. Edwarde Cratford, Rychard Elithorn, Iohn Wright.
☞ Alſo Mayſter yonge of hymſelf doth declare further, touching the former Articles on this wyſe.

div.head: ❧ To the .v. Article.
div.p:
IN Primis that Doctor Redmā ſayd more, where as S. Auguſtine ſayd: Quod Iudas idem accepīt ꝙ Petrus, that Iudas receiued the ſame that Peter dyd, he ſayde: that he vnderſtode that of the ſacramente, and that after thee ſame phraſe a manne myghte ſaye: Quod Simon magus idem Baptiſma recepit quod Apoſtoli, That Symon Magus receaued the ſame
baptiſme that the Apoſtles dyd, when he dyd receaue only the outward ſacrament to his condēpnaciō, for he ſayd that he thought: chriſt wold not vouchſafe to geue his holy fleſhe to an vngodly man, and thys he ſayd was alwayes his minde, though he knew that other men dyd otherwyſe thinke.

div.head: ❧ To the .vi. Article.
div.p: Item he ſayd: he neuer lyked the cariage about of the ſacrament, & preached agaynſte it, aboute a .xvi. yeares ſince in Cambridge.

div.head: ❧ To the .x. Article.
div.p:
Item when he was demaunded of tranſubſtantiacion, he ſaid: that he had trauayled about it, & thinckinge that the doubtes whych he perceyued dyd ryſe thereon, ſhuld be made playne by the ſchole men, dyd reade theyr bokes, and that after that he had read them that the opinion of tranſubſtantiaciō was
euery daye magis & magis languida that is, weaker and weaker, & that there was no ſoch tranſubſtantiacion as they made, addinge therto that ye whole ſchole dyd not know what was meant by conſecration, which he ſayd was the whole action of the holy Communion.

div.head: ☞ To the .xiii. Article.
div.p: Item he ſayd that he dyd repent him that he had ſo moch ſtriued agaynſt iuſtification by only fayth.

div.head: ☞ To the .xiiii. Article.
div.p: Item that worckes hadde theyr crowne and reward, but that they dyd not deſerue eternall lyfe & the Kingdom of God, no not the workes of grace, Nam domini dei vita eterna. For euerlaſtinge lyfe is the gyfte of God.

div.head: ¶ A Note of the Communication that I Rychard Wilkes had with M. D. Redman, beyng ſycke at Weſtmynſter, but of good memorie the ſeconde daye of Nouēber. 1551. in the preſence of Maſter Yong, & an other whom I dyd not know, and two of M. D. Redmans ſeruātes, the one called Elliſe and the other vnknowen.
div.p:
I Wyſhed him health in ſoule and bodye, and doubted not but more he did practiſe the godly counſayl in him ſelf, the whych he was wonte to geue to other, beyng in his caſe, & thanckes be to god, who had geuē hym ſtuffe of knowledge to cōforte him ſelfe withal. Sayth he, God of all
comfort geue me grace to haue cō forte in him, and to haue my mynd wholye fyxed in hym. Mayſter yonge and I ſayde Amen. Then I communed wyth hym of his ſickeneſſe, and the weakeneſſe of hys bodye, & though he were brought neuer ſo low, yet he, yf it were his pleaſure that rayſed vp Lazarus, coulde reſtore hym too healthe agayne, No no, ſayeth he: that is paſte, and I deſyre it not, but thee wyll of God be fulfylled. After thys a lyttle other lyke communicatyon, I aſked yf I myghte be ſo bolde not troublynge hym, too knowe hys mynde for my learnynge in ſome matters and poynctes of Relygyon, he ſayde: yea, and that he was as glad to common wyth me in ſoche matters as wyth anye manne, and then I ſayde to hys ſeruaunces: I truſte I ſhall not trouble him, no ſayde
Ellys his ſeruaunte, my Lorde of London M. Nowell, and other haue comuned wyth him, and he was glad of it. Then ſayd Maſter Redman no you ſhall not trouble me, I pray god euer geue me grace to ſpeake the trueth, & hys trueth, and that which ſhall redounde to hys glory, and ſēd vs vnitie in hys church, and we ſayd. Amen. I ſaid he ſhuld do moch good in declaringe hys fayth, and I wold be glad to knowe his mynde, as touching thee Sacramente of thee bodye and bloude of Chriſt, he ſayde as man is made of two partes, of the body, and the ſoule, ſo chriſt wold fede thee whole man, but what ſaith he be the wordes of the text, let vs take the wordes of the ſcripture, and he rehearſed the text him ſelf thus, Accepit Ieſus panem, chriſte toke breade, wherein hys wyll was to inſtytute a Sacramente,
Accipite commedite, take, eat, here he tolde thee vſe of it, what didde he geue thē? Hoc eſt corpus meum, He calleth it his body. Then I aſked him of the preſence of Chriſte, he ſayd: Chriſt was preſente wyth his ſacramēt, and in thoſe that receaued it as they ought. And ther was mira vnitio, a wonderful vnion (for that word was named) betwixt Chriſt & vs, as ſ. Paule ſaith Vos eſtis, os ex oſſibus eius, et caro ex carne eius, ye be bone of his bones, & fleſhe of hys fleſhe, the whyche vnion was ineffable. Then I aſked him what he thought of the opinion that Chriſte was ther corporally, naturally, & really, he aunſwered yf you meane by corporally, naturally, & really, yt he is ther preſent, Vere, I graunt. Thē I aſked him howe he thoughte of that which was wont commenly to be ſpoken, that chriſt was ther fleſhe
bloud, and bone, as I haue heard the ſtewardes in theyr leetes geue charge, whē the ſixe Articles ſtode in effecte, and dyd geue charge too thinqueſt to enquyre, that yf there were anye that woulde denye that Chriſt was preſent in the Sacrament of the aulter, in fleſhe, bloud, and bone, they ſhuld preſent them. He ſayd: that was to to groſſe, and could not wel be excuſed from the opiniō of the Caphernites. Thē I aſked him in aſmoch, as chriſt was there, Vere, howe doo we receaue hym in oure myndes and ſpirituall partes, or wyth oure mouthes and into our bodies, or bothe? he ſaid: we receaue him in our mindes and ſoules by fayth. Then in aſmoche as he was moch in this point, that there was Mira vnitio, a merueylous vnion, betwixt vs and Chriſt, in that we were Caro ex carne eius, et os ex oſſibus, bone of his bones
and fleſhe of hys fleſhe, I deſyred to knowe his opiniō, whether we receaued the very body of Chriſte wyth our mouthes, & into our bodyes, or no. Here he pauſed and dyd holde his peace a lytle ſpace, & ſhortely after he ſpake, ſayinge: I wyl not ſaye ſo, I can not tel, it is a harde queſtion, but ſurely ſayth he: we receaue Chriſt in our ſoule by fayth, when you ſpeake of it other wayes, it ſoundeth groſſely, & ſauoureth of thee Caphernites. Then I aſked him what he thought of that whych the Prieſt was wont to lyft vp and ſhow the people betwixt his handes, he ſayd: it is the ſacrament, then ſayd I they were wont to worſhyp that which was lifted vp, yea ſaith he: but we muſt worſhip chriſt in heuē, Chriſt is nether lifted vp nor down, I am glad ſayde I Maſter D. to heare you ſaye ſo moche, I woulde not
ſpeake of the holy ſacramēt otherwyſe then reuerentlye, but I feare leſt that ſacrament and lytle white pece of breade ſo lyfted vp, hathe robbed Chryſte of a greate parte of his honour. Thē ſayd he loking vp and prayinge, god graunte vs grace that we maye haue the true vnderſtandyng of his word, wherby we may come to the true vſe of his Sacramentes, & ſayd he wold neuer allowe the carying about of the ſacrament & other fond abuſes aboute the ſame. Then after a litle whyle pawſyng ſayd I, Mayſter Doctoure yf I ſhulde not trouble you, I wolde praye you to knowe your mynde in tranſubſtantiacion, Ieſu Mayſter Wilkes ſayeth he wyll you aſke me that? Syr ſayde I, not yf I ſhulde trouble you, no no, I wyl tel you ſayth he, becauſe I founde thopinion of tranſubſtā ciation receiued in the church, whē
I hard it ſpokē againſt, I ſerched the auncient Doctors diligently, & went about to ſtabliſhe it by them, becauſe it was receaued, and whē I redde manye of theym, I founde lyttle for it, and could not be ſatiſfyed, then I went to the ſcole doctours, and namely to Gabriel, and wayed hys reaſons, the whyche when I had done, and perceaued they were no pithier, Langueſcebat opinio mea, de tranſubſtantiatione, my opinion of tranſubſtantiacion waxed feble, and then ſayth he: I retourned agayne to Tertullian & Ireneus, and when I hadde obſerued theyr ſayinges, myne opinion that there ſhuld be tranſubſtantiacion, Prorſus erat abolita, was quyte daſſhed. Then ſayde I, you knowe that the ſcole Doctors dyd holde that Panis nō remanebat poſt conſecrationem, that bread remayned not after conſecration, as they
called it. The ſcole Doctors ſayth he: dyd not know what conſecratio doeth meane, and here he pauſed a whyle, I praye you ſayd I, what ſaye you yt conſecratio doth meane, ſayth he: it is Tota actio in miniſtering the Sacramēt as Chriſt dyd inſtitute it. All the whole thinge done in the miniſterie as Chriſt ordeyned it, that is conſecratio, and what, ſayth he: nede we to doubte that bread remayneth. Scripture calleth it bread and certayne good Auctours that be of latter tyme, be of that opinion.

After that I hadde communed with Mayſter D. Redman, & takē my leaue of hym, Mayſter Yonge came forth into the nexte chambre with me, to whom I ſayde: that I was glad to ſe Maſter D. Redmā ſo wel mynded, then ſayth Maſter Yonge to me, I am ſure he wyll not deny it, I enſure you ſayth he:
Maſter D. hath ſo moued me that wher as I was of that opiniō before in certayne thinges, that I woulde haue burned and loſt my lyfe for them, now ſayth Mayſter yonge, I doubt of them, but I ſee ſayth he: a man ſhall knowe more and more by proces of tyme, and readinge and hearinge of others, and Maiſter D. Redmans ſaying ſhall cauſe me too loke more dylygently for them.

Item that Ellis Mayſter Doctour Redmans ſeruaunte ſhewed me, that he dydde knowe that hys Mayſter had declared too Kynge Henrye the .viii. his Maieſtie, that faith onely iuſtifieth, but that doctryne as he thought was not to be taught the people, leaſt they ſhuld be negligent to do good workes.

The ſayd M. yonge hath reported, the whych alſo I hearde that Mayſter Doctour Redman ſhuld
ſaye, that conſenſus Eccleſie the cō ſent of the Church was but a weake ſtaffe to cleaue to, but dyd exhorte hym to reade the ſcriptures, for ther was that which ſhuld comfort him, whē he ſhulde be in ſoche caſe as he was then.
❀ Imprinted at London by Thomas Raynalde in Paules churche yeald for Wylliam Seres, dwellyng at the weſt ſyde of Paules towarde Ludgate, at the ſigne of the hedgehog.
